head.title: Sorters and Gizmos to Ease the Wash Load

hedline.hl1: Sorters and Gizmos to Ease the Wash Load

abstract.p: Article describes some of numerous items to sort clothes and otherwise make washing and ironing clothes easier; photos (M)

block.p: I MUST admit, I do get a small sense of satisfaction from a pile of clean clothes and an empty hamper.
It's a fleeting victory, though, because laundry is in the same league as dirty dishes and backyard dandelions -- quick to regenerate and relentlessly in need of attention.
I MUST admit, I do get a small sense of satisfaction from a pile of clean clothes and an empty hamper.
It's a fleeting victory, though, because laundry is in the same league as dirty dishes and backyard dandelions -- quick to regenerate and relentlessly in need of attention.

Is it any wonder, then, that there are so many products designed to arm us for our battles with our dirty clothes and to make life in the laundry room a little brighter, easier and even fun? Here are a few options:
Gathering your soiled belongings and getting them to the washing machine are steps that can't be skipped when it comes to laundry.

Bed, Bath and Beyond stocks an array of items for this task, ranging from simple mesh bags ($6.99) to a three-bin mesh laundry sorter for whites, colors and delicates ($19.99) to a deluxe sorter ($79.99). That upscale version is a chrome model on wheels, with three removable cotton-canvas bags and a shelf on top.

The Frontgate catalog features a similar sorter, with the addition of a rod for hangables under the shelf ($99). The Frontgate catalog can be ordered by calling (800) 626-6488 or on the Internet: www.frontgate.com. Restoration Hardware in The Westchester features its Desoto laundry basket, a circular number on wheels with a chrome-plated frame and one large canvas bag ($55).

When it comes to hampers, Bed, Bath and Beyond has two inexpensive mesh versions, one that fits into a corner and one that is oval shaped (both $9.99). For those planning to do laundry when they travel, look for the Pop-Up Hamper ($9.99). It folds to the size of half a breadbox and opens up to a full-size, two-load hamper with handles.

What about places to put things? Bed, Bath and Beyond has a Rolling Laundry Organizer ($19.99), which is three shelves on wheels and narrow enough to slide between the washer and dryer when it's not being used.
Frontgate offers a wall-mounted clothes drying rack, which retracts into a chrome-finished cover and can be hidden when not in use ($59 for five rods; $79 for eight rods).

Fels-Naptha? Gonzo? Oust? You might not pick these oddly named items as cleaning products, but read on. At Restoration Hardware, check out Fels-Naptha, a heavy-duty bar soap (five bars, $8.50) with prewash spot-removing powers (it's also touted as a treatment for poison ivy and a garden pest repellent). Gonzo, as its name suggests, is a highly recommended stain remover, which works on clothes as well as carpets, upholstery and vinyl ($3.95).

Who would have thought you would need to wash the washing machine? Oust Cleaner ($2.95) cycles through the machine when it is empty of clothes, ridding it of the accumulated build-up you never knew was there but will surely be relieved to know is gone.

Choosing environmentally safe laundry products can reduce build-up from the start, delivering just-as-clean clothes without the pollutants. Mrs. Green's Natural Market, with stores throughout Westchester, carries environmentally sound laundry detergents from Bio-Kleen, Bio-Pac, Seventh Generation, Ecover and Earth Friendly.

Shaklee, the California-based mail-order business with several representatives in Westchester, offers its Basic-L line of laundry products, which are hypo-allergenic and free of phosphates, chlorine, borates and nitrates.

As for the dry cleaner, the problem is that you have to go there. Twice. And you have to wait, sometimes days, before you can pick up your belongings -- unless you decide to do your dry cleaning at home.

Dryel provides a reusable, plastic clothes bag and dryer-activated cleaning cloths. Your dry-clean-onlys tumble with the cloth in the bag for 30 minutes and come out clean and somehow unwrinkled. (Available at Wal-Mart, Kmart, Target and Sam's Club; 12 cloths for cleaning up to 48 garments are in the kit, $19.99 at Sam's Club). Bed, Bath and Beyond sells its own version, called Custom Cleaner ($8.99 for three loads).

Sometimes it's not stains that take you to the dry cleaner, but unpleasant, lingering odors from perspiration, smoke or perfume. A lot of time, cost and wear and tear on clothes can be avoided with the Sharper Image Ionic Closet Dry Cleaner. ($89.95; compact model, $49.95). It's a clothes freshener that you put in your closet, hanging on the wall or from the rod, or standing on the floor. It's smaller than a breadbox and runs 24 hours a day, silently circulating natural ozone to neutralize unwanted smells in all kinds of fabrics.

So, can ironing be made easier? Or is that a contradiction in terms? Perhaps not. Frontgate's European Ironing Board ($149) comes with two shelves, one below to hold items already pressed, the other a side extension to spread out clothes. And if that's not enough, their Ironing Stool ($79) positions you at the perfect height for ironing in comfort.
